subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] get your news in QS!
msgSnippet: Paul: I thought after I wrote the comment about being more fluent in reading QS that it might be disconcerting.  I read two of the articles in the News in QS
messageBody:
Paul:

I thought after I wrote the comment about being more fluent in reading QS that it might be disconcerting.  I read two of the articles in the News in QS with interest today, and I have been reading what others are writing by hand in QS without problems in recent weeks.  I write it fluently just as Moira mentioned she does.  The problem is not with QS but with the amount of practice that we receive.  I just cannot read QS as fast as TO, which is not surprising when you consider that we are surrounded by TO all the time and that we learned it as children. I daresay that if as a child you had been told how TO worked, but were given no reading practice in it, no one around you used it, and you never received anything written in it, you would be just as slow at reading TO as you are now at reading QS.

I would like to attain the reading speed in QS that I have in TO.  That goal is still some distance away, but it is getting closer.  For the first time, with the ability to communicate effectively in QS and to read articles, news, etc. written in it, I have no question that goal can be attained.  I can already see that my QS reading speed has been increasing in recent weeks.  And even now, I'm not reading QS every day.

Just as a beginning TO reader sounds words out, we have to do that in QS until we begin to automatically recognize word outlines.  Until recently that has not been feasible because there are too few of us, and we tend to only read what we write ourselves.  For instance, I take notes in QS as secretary of a club I'm in.  I then go back and transliterate them on the computer for the club records.  Thus, my reading speed isn't critical and QS is still useful. 

A fluent reader recognizes words at sight and doesn't have to break them down into individual syllables or letters.  However, in reading your news today, I saw numerous words in QS for the first time.  The shorter, common words I read quickly and essentially automatically just as I do in TO.  But three, four and five syllable words that are unfamiliar are a different matter.  Here are a few words I remember reading in QS for the first time today, and there are countless others: Islamabad, Islamic militants, Afghanistan, Land Cruiser, bullet-proofed (this last one hasn't come up much in my personal note-taking.)   :-).

Since the term "Islamic militants" was in the Pakistan story several times, it began looking familiar by the end of the story, but that is what has to occur to build up reading speed.


Paige

P.S.  Here is an example of the pressure we face against using QS.  A few years ago, I was taking notes in QS in a case.  Later my father, with whom I practiced, would be looking at a file, and tell me that I needed to write in TO.  His customary comment was, "What if you get hit by a bus, and I have to take this case over.  I won't be able to read your notes."  The same problem exists when my secretary is working on a document and has to refer to the file.  If there are notes in QS, I have to rewrite them for her, which isn't exactly a time-saver.

What would be interesting would be for someone to teach their child to read QS before they go to school and see how easily they take to it.



Paul Tremblay wrote:

Paige Gabhart wrote:
>
>
> Paul:
>
> Let me add my superlatives to the others. News in QS just blew me
> away. One of our big problems was providing interesting items for
> reading practice. This solves that problem beautifully. It also makes
> me realize how much more reading practice I need to get truly fluent in
> reading QS.
>

Thanks everyone for the compliments. The thing is, I did this as kind of
an afterthought. I guess it was lucky I did. I didn't realize so many
people would like it so much.

It is a bit disconcerting to hear that even you, who has used QS since
the 70s, struggles reading QS. Can one use QS the way one uses TO, and
be able to read what you write and what others write?

Paul
